intro: Styphelia leucopogon, commonly known as the white-tipped snowbell, is a flowering plant native to the coastal regions of southern Australia. It is a low-growing shrub that typically reaches a height of about 10 to 30 centimeters. The plant features small, white or pale pink flowers that bloom in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are narrow and leathery, adapted to withstand the harsh coastal conditions. Styphelia leucopogon is often found in heathlands and sandy soils, where it thrives in full sun to partial shade.
